data.title: The Breakfast Club, The Lion King Join Other Classics in the National
data.meta_description: Plus Thelma and Louise, Paris Is Burning, and more.
data.text:
Thelma and Louise just rode its way into the National Film Registry at the Library of Congress. On Wednesday, librarian of Congress Carla Hayden announced the 25 new films that have been added to the registry; among its picks are popular classics like Disney’s The Lion King, Barbra Streisand’s Funny Girl, and the John Hughes high-school drama The Breakfast Club.

The film selection has become an annual tradition. The head librarian, along with the National Film Preservation Board and library specialists, pluck out movies that are “culturally, historically or aesthetically significant.” Public nominations are also considered.

Another film joining the registry this year is legendary drag-queen documentary Paris Is Burning. Released in 1990, the Jennie Livingston–directed film documents the competitive ball scene and L.G.B.T. community in New York City in the 1980s.

Alfred Hitchcock’s The Birds was also selected, joining other previously selected Hitchcock classics like Pyscho and North by Northwest. The Birds, in particular, however, popped up in headlines earlier this year when star Tippi Hedren revealed the sexual abuse and harassment she endured from Hitchcock while making both this film and Marnie.

Comedy fans will be glad to see the 1987 Rob Reiner film The Princess Bride join the registry as well, while Wes Anderson fans will happily note Rushmore’s selection. The quirky high-school film stars Bill Murray and Jason Schwartzman as a pair of unlikely friends. Who Framed Roger Rabbit, the half-animated, half-live-action comedy directed by Robert Zemeckis, was also selected this year.

One of the oldest films to join the registry is The Musketeers of Pig Alley, released in 1912. Directed by D.W. Griffith, it’s considered the first gangster film ever made and clocks in at a brisk 17 minutes. There’s also Life of an American Fireman, directed by film pioneer Edwin S. Porter and released in 1903.

Here are the 25 films that made the cut this year:

The Atomic Cafe (1982)

Ball of Fire (1941)

The Beau Brummels (1928)

The Birds The (1963)

Blackboard Jungle (1955)

The Breakfast Club (1985)

The Decline of Western Civilization (1981)

East of Eden (1955)

Funny Girl (1968)

Life of an American Fireman (1903)

The Lion King (1994)

Lost Horizon (1937)

The Musketeers of Pig Alley (1912)

Paris Is Burning (1990)

Point Blank (1967)

The Princess Bride (1987)

Putney Swope (1969)

Rushmore (1998)

Solomon Sir Jones films (1924-28)

Steamboat Bill, Jr. (1928)

Suzanne, Suzanne (1982)

Thelma & Louise (1991)

20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (1916)

A Walk in the Sun (1945)

Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988)

National Film Registry

Ghostbusters, Top Gun, and Film About a Sneeze Are Officially Preserved for History

The National Film Registry makes more of its delightfully diverse choices.

The Canon

Proof That Forrest Gump Is a Work of Art

If MoMA says so, it must be true.

Politics

Could Global Tensions Puncture the Olympic Bubble?

The Olympics are often viewed as a respite from politics, but multiple wars and rising global tensions will be hard to ignore this year. “I’m here to bring awareness,” says Valerie Tarazi, a swimmer representing Palestine at the 2024 Summer Games.

Hollywood

Trump’s Politics Aside, Do We Want a President With Pop-Culture References This Old?

“The late, great Hannibal Lecter. He’s a wonderful man.” “Nobody could moonwalk like Michael Jackson.” “You know how many times I did The View?” Now that Biden is out of the race, please consider that these are actual statements Donald Trump has recently made.

Hollywood

Inside Kamala Harris’s Loyal Circle of Hollywood Friends

“I used to say, ‘I wish voters saw the Kamala we know.’ And I feel like in the last 24 hours, more people are.”

Award Season

Joan Chen Has Always Been a Movie Star. Hollywood Is Finally Catching Up

The veteran actor has worked with Bernardo Bertolucci, David Lynch, and Ang Lee, and maintained rich careers in both China and the US. With the new film Dìdi, Oscar buzz is trailing her for the first time. What took so long?

Movies

Why Was Jessica Chastain and Anne Hathaway’s New Movie Buried?

Mothers’ Instinct is a perfectly solid domestic thriller with two Oscar-winning movie stars that barely got a North American release.

Style

Inside Kensington Palace: Explore the Royal Family’s Storied Home

Kensington Palace may be smaller than nearby Buckingham Palace, but its history is far richer and much more scandalous.

Television

These 2024 Summer Olympic Athletes Have Main-Character Energy

From a cheese-wheel-toting Italian gymnast to an Egyptian fencer who competed while seven months pregnant, here’s a guide to the athletes who went viral at the Paris Games.
